docs.title: Making diffraction data analysis easy
docs.text:
EasyDiffraction is a scientific software for the calculation of neutron powder diffraction pattern based on a structural model and refinement of its parameters against experimental data.

EasyDiffraction is distributed both as a cross-platform desktop application and as a Python library.

Here you can find how to use the EasyDiffraction python library. The EasyDiffraction graphical user interface documentation can be found elsewhere.

docs.title: Change minimizer
docs.text:
This example shows how to change the minimization engine for refinement.

docs.title: TOF NCAF-WISH
docs.text:
This example shows how to refine the crystal structure parameters of Si from neutron diffraction data in a time-of-flight experiment performed on SEPD diffractometer at Argonne.

In [2]: Copied! 
import easydiffraction as ed
import easydiffraction as ed

Create a job — the main object to store all the information

In [3]: Copied! 
job = ed.Job(type='tof')
job = ed.Job(type='tof')

Load a phase from CIF file

In [4]: Copied! 
job.add_phase_from_file('data/ncaf.cif')
print(job.phases)
job.add_phase_from_file('data/ncaf.cif') print(job.phases) 
Collection of 1 phases: ['ncaf']

Show phase info in CIF format

phase = job.phases['ncaf']
print(phase.cif)

docs.title: TOF Si-SEPD
docs.text:
This example shows how to refine the crystal structure parameters of Si from neutron diffraction data in a time-of-flight experiment performed on SEPD diffractometer at Argonne.

In [2]: Copied! 
import easydiffraction as ed
import easydiffraction as ed

Create a job — the main object to store all the information

In [3]: Copied! 
job = ed.Job(type='tof')
job = ed.Job(type='tof')

Create a phase object

In [4]: Copied! 
phase = ed.Phase(name='si')
phase = ed.Phase(name='si')

Set space group

In [5]: Copied! 
phase.space_group.name_hm_alt = 'F d -3 m'
phase.space_group.name_hm_alt = 'F d -3 m'

Set cell parameters

In [6]: Copied! 
phase.cell.length_a = 5.43146
phase.cell.length_a = 5.43146

Add atoms

In [7]: Copied! 
phase.atom_sites.append(label='Si',
                        type_symbol='Si',
                        fract_x=0,
                        fract_y=0,
                        fract_z=0,
                        occupancy=1,
                        b_iso_or_equiv=0.529)
phase.atom_sites.append(label='Si', type_symbol='Si', fract_x=0, fract_y=0, fract_z=0, occupancy=1, b_iso_or_equiv=0.529)

Add phase to the job object

In [8]: Copied! 
job.add_phase(phase=phase)
print(job.phases)
job.add_phase(phase=phase) print(job.phases)

2, 1
The default value has been choosen:'2'.

print(phase.cif)
phase = job.phases['si'] print(phase.cif)

docs.title: Install EasyDiffraction python library
docs.text:
The latest release of EasyDiffraction can be installed with PIP from PyPI: 

pip install easydiffraction

Installing an unreleased version is not recommended and should only be done for testing purposes. Here is an example of how to install EasyDiffraction directly from a GitHub repository, e.g. from the develop branch: 

pip install git+https://github.com/EasyScience/EasyDiffractionLib@develop

docs.title: Install Jupyter Notebook to run examples
Locally
docs.text:
• Install easydiffraction with charts extras for visualization 
    pip install 'easydiffraction[charts]'
  • Install Jupyter Notebook 
    pip install notebook
  • Download EasyDiffraction examples from GitHub, e.g., using curl (if not done already) 
    curl https://codeload.github.com/easyscience/EasyDiffractionLib/tar.gz/develop | tar -xz --strip=1 EasyDiffractionLib-develop/examples
  • Run Jupyter Notebook server 
    jupyter notebook examples/
  • Open your web browser and go to 
    http://localhost:8888/
  • Select one of the *.ipynb files

docs.title: Via Google Colab (interactive, requires google account)
docs.text: • At the very top of each example from the How to use section, there is a button to

docs.title: Abbreviations
docs.text: This page contains the most common abbreviation labels used in EasyDiffraction documentation.

docs.title: Dictionary type labels
docs.text:
• coreCIF Core CIF dictionary by the IUCr.
  • pdCIF Powder CIF dictionary by the IUCr.
  • customCIF Custom CIF dictionary by the EasyDiffraction developers.

docs.title: Neutron diffraction
docs.text:
• pd-neut-cwl Powder neutron diffraction with constant wavelength.
  • pd-neut-tof Powder neutron diffraction with time-of-flight.
  • sc-neut-cwl Single crystal neutron diffraction with constant wavelength.

docs.title: X-ray diffraction
docs.text: • pd-xray Powder X-ray diffraction.

docs.text: All names for describing the EasyDiffraction project are divided into several dictionaries given below. Each keyword in the dictionaries has one badge showing the corresponding type of dictionary, and can have one or more badges showing the type of experiment to which the keyword belongs.

docs.title: Project structure
docs.text: Input/output files for EasyDiffraction are in simple and human-readable data format STAR/CIF with the specifications of International Union of Crystallography, where possible.

docs.title: CIF-based project files
docs.text:
Example project structure for the constant wavelength powder neutron diffraction measurement is given below:

La0.5Ba0.5CoO3     - Project directory.
├── project.cif    - Main project description file.
├── models         - Folder with individual crystallographic phases.
│   ├── lbco.cif   - File with La0.5Ba0.5CoO3 phase parameters.
│   └── ...
├── experiments    - Folder with instrumental parameters and measured data.
│   ├── hrpt.cif   - Measured data from HRPT@PSI & instrumental parameters.
│   └── ...
└── summary
    └── report.cif - Summary report after structure refinement.

Here is the content of the project files:

docs.title: project.cif
docs.text:
data_La0.5Ba0.5CoO3

_project.description "neutrons, powder, constant wavelength, HRPT@PSI"

loop_
_model.cif_file_name
lbco.cif

loop_
_experiment.cif_file_name
hrpt.cif

docs.title: Other supported data files
docs.text:
If you do not have a CIF file with both the instrumental parameters and measured data, as in the example above (hrpt.cif), you can import only measured data, which are then automatically converted into CIF with default parameters. These can be later edited in the application.

The following measured data formats are supported:

  • If standard deviations of measured intensities are present, the file should have either *.xye or *.xys extension and contain the following 3 columns: _pd_meas.2theta_scan, _pd_meas.intensity_total and _pd_meas.intensity_total_su.
  • If standard deviations of measured intensities are not given, the file should have *.xy extension and contain the following 2 columns: _pd_meas.2theta_scan and _pd_meas.intensity_total. In this case, the _pd_meas.intensity_total_su is calculated as the square root of _pd_meas.intensity_total.

Optional comments with # are possible in data file headers.

Here are some examples:

docs.title: atom site
docs.text: coreCIF

docs.title: _atom_site
docs.text: Data items in this category record details about the atom sites in a crystal structure, such as the positional coordinates and atomic displacement parameters. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _atom_site.label
docs.text: This is a unique identifier for a particular site in the asymmetric unit of the crystal unit cell.

docs.title: _atom_site.type_symbol
docs.text: A code to identify the atom specie(s) occupying this site.

docs.title: _atom_site.fract
docs.text:
Atom-site coordinates as fractions of the _cell_length values.

  • _atom_site.fract_x
  • _atom_site.fract_y
  • _atom_site.fract_z

docs.title: _atom_site.occupancy
docs.text: The fraction of the atom type present at this site.

docs.title: _atom_site.ADP_type
docs.text: Code for type of atomic displacement parameters used for the site. Currently only Biso (isotropic B) is supported.

docs.title: _atom_site.B_iso_or_equiv
docs.text: Isotropic atomic displacement parameter, or equivalent isotropic atomic displacement parameter, in angstroms squared.

docs.title: _atom_site.site_symmetry_multiplicity
docs.text:
optional parameter

The number of different sites that are generated by the application of the space-group symmetry to the coordinates given for this site. It is equal to the multiplicity given for this Wyckoff site in International Tables for Crystallography Vol. A (2002).

docs.title: _atom_site.Wyckoff_symbol
docs.text:
optional parameter

The Wyckoff symbol (letter) as listed in the space-group tables of International Tables for Crystallography Vol. A.

docs.title: cell
docs.text: coreCIF

docs.title: _cell
docs.text: Data items in this category record details about the crystallographic cell parameters and their measurement. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _cell.angle
docs.text:
The angles between the bounding cell axes in degrees.

  • _cell.angle_alpha
  • _cell.angle_beta
  • _cell.angle_gamma

docs.title: _cell.length
docs.text:
The lengths of each cell axis in angstroms.

  • _cell.length_a
  • _cell.length_b
  • _cell.length_c

docs.title: diffrn radiation
docs.text: coreCIF

docs.title: _diffrn_radiation
docs.text: Data items in this category describe the radiation used in measuring the diffraction intensities. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _diffrn_radiation.probe
docs.text:
The nature of the radiation used (i.e. the name of the subatomic particle or the region of the electromagnetic spectrum).

Supported values: neutron and x-ray

docs.title: diffrn radiation wavelength
docs.text: coreCIF

docs.title: _diffrn_radiation_wavelength
docs.text: Data items in this category describe the wavelength of radiation used in diffraction measurements. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _diffrn_radiation_wavelength.wavelength
docs.text: Wavelength of the radiation used to measure the unit cell.

docs.title: exptl crystal
docs.text: customCIF

docs.title: extinction
docs.text: customCIF

docs.title: pd background
docs.text: pdCIF

docs.title: _pd_background
docs.text: This category defines various background functions that could be used when calculating diffractograms. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _pd_background.line_segment_X
docs.text:
List of X-coordinates used to create many straight-line segments representing the background in a calculated diffractogram.

Supported values: 2theta and time-of-flight

docs.title: _pd_background.line_segment_intensity
docs.text: List of intensities used to create many straight-line segments representing the background in a calculated diffractogram.

docs.title: _pd_background.X_coordinate
docs.text: The type of X-coordinate against which the pd_background values were calculated.

docs.title: pd calib
docs.text: customCIF

docs.title: _pd_calib
docs.text: This section defines the parameters used for the calibration of the instrument, similar to this IUCr section.

docs.title: _pd_calib.2theta_offset
docs.text: An offset angle (in degrees) used to calibrate 2θ.

docs.title: pd instr
docs.text: customCIF

docs.title: _pd_instr
docs.text: This section contains information relevant to the instrument used for the diffraction measurement, similar to this IUCr section.

docs.title: _pd_instr.resolution
docs.text:
In general, the profile of a Bragg reflection centred at the peak position can be approximated by mathematical convolution of contributions from the instrument, called the instrumental resolution function, and from the microstructure of the sample. Because many contributions to powder diffraction peaks have a nearly Gaussian or Lorentzian shape, the pseudo-Voigt function, is widely used to describe peak profiles in powder diffraction.

Half-width parameters (normally characterising the instrumental resolution function) as implemented in CrysPy:

  • _pd_instr.resolution_u
  • _pd_instr.resolution_v
  • _pd_instr.resolution_w

Lorentzian isotropic microstrain parameter as implemented in CrysPy:

  • _pd_instr.resolution_x

Lorentzian isotropic particle size parameteras implemented in CrysPy:

  • _pd_instr.resolution_y

docs.title: _pd_instr.reflex_asymmetry
docs.text:
Peak profile asymmetry parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

  • _pd_instr.reflex_asymmetry_p1
  • _pd_instr.reflex_asymmetry_p2
  • _pd_instr.reflex_asymmetry_p3
  • _pd_instr.reflex_asymmetry_p4

docs.title: _pd_instr.2theta_bank
docs.text: Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

docs.title: _pd_instr.dtt
docs.text:
Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

  • _pd_instr.dtt1
  • _pd_instr.dtt2

docs.title: _pd_instr.zero
docs.text: Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

docs.title: _pd_instr.alpha
docs.text:
Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

  • _pd_instr.alpha0
  • _pd_instr.alpha1

docs.title: _pd_instr.beta
docs.text:
Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

  • _pd_instr.beta0
  • _pd_instr.beta1

docs.title: _pd_instr.sigma
docs.text:
Time-of-flight parameters as implemented in CrysPy.

  • _pd_instr.sigma0
  • _pd_instr.sigma1
  • _pd_instr.sigma2

docs.title: pd meas
docs.text: pdCIF

docs.title: _pd_meas
docs.text: This section contains the measured diffractogram, similar to this IUCr section.

docs.title: _pd_meas.2theta_scan
docs.text: 2θ diffraction angle (in degrees) for intensity points measured in a scanning method.

docs.title: _pd_meas.time-of-flight
docs.text: Measured time (in microseconds) for time-of-flight neutron measurements.

docs.title: _pd_meas.intensity_total
docs.text: Intensity recorded at each measurement point as a function of angle.

docs.title: _pd_meas.intensity_total_su
docs.text: Standard uncertainty of _pd_meas.2theta_scan.

docs.title: pd phase
docs.text: pdCIF

docs.title: _pd_phase_block
docs.text: A table of phases relevant to the current data block. Each phase is identified by its data block identifier. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _pd_phase_block.id
docs.text: A block ID code identifying a block containing phase information.

docs.title: _pd_phase_block.scale
docs.text: Phase scale.

docs.title: space group
docs.text: coreCIF

docs.title: _space_group
docs.text: Contains all the data items that refer to the space group as a whole. Please see the IUCr page for further details.

docs.title: _space_group.name_H-M_alt
docs.text: The international Hermann-Mauguin space-group symbol as defined in International Tables for Crystallography Volume A. It allows any Hermann-Mauguin symbol to be given.

docs.title: _space_group.IT_coordinate_system_code
docs.text: A qualifier taken from the enumeration list identifying which setting in International Tables for Crystallography Volume A (2002) (IT) is used.
